abstract.p: This paper examines the performance of 648 initial public offerings (IPOs) listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) from June 1992 to March 2002 over a five-year period. Voluminous research across the world suggests that IPOs unanimously witness very high returns in the short run; as opposed to it, the long-run performance of IPOs does not observe any ubiquitous pattern and this paper is an attempt to draw conclusions about the performance of IPOs in India. In order to get robust conclusions on IPO performance, the patterns of IPO performance have been analyzed for 60 months subsequent to listing. Furthermore, the study attempts to find out the factors that determine the performance of Indian IPOs.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Voluminous financial literature exists on the various aspects of initial public offerings across the world and of which a more dominant aspect is share price performance of IPOs. The testing of initial returns have resulted in universally accepted underpricing (see for example, Aggarwal, Leal and Hernandez, 1993; Ghosh, 2005; Ibbotson, 1975; Levis, 1993; Ljungqvist, 1997; Madhusoodan and Thrirpalraju, 1997; Peavy, 1990; Ritter, 1984, 1987; Sehgal and Singh, 2008; Singh and Mittal, 2003; Tinic, 1988; etc.). Conversely, the testing of the long-run performance has generated varied results in different countries (see Table 1). In fact, it is puzzling to know that same IPOs which give very high returns to investors in the initial period tend to underperform in the long run. By definition, the long-run performance of issuing firms is measured by stock-price performance over a long time, generally from one year to five years after the IPO. The major result, broadly accepted but recently put into question, is that IPOs perform badly over one to five years following their introduction in the stock market (Boutron et al., 2007). The issue of long-run performance of IPOs has received increased attention since Ritter’s (1991) exposure of the potential wealth hazard of a buy-and-hold strategy toward investing in IPOs (Hensler et al., 1997). Validating Ritter’s (1991) findings, studies in several countries have confirmed the existence of long-run underperformance after one (Aggarwal and Rivoli,1990), three (Aggarwal et al., 1993; Cai and Wei, 1997; Lee et al., 1994; Ljungqvist, 1997; Loughran et al., 1994; etc.), five (Espenlaub et al., 2000; Kooli and Suret, 2003; Loughran and Ritter, 1995; etc.) and six years (Loughran, 1993).

The phenomenon of IPO’s long-run underperformance appears to hold internationally. However, the exception to the globally observed underperformance is reported by Kim et al. (1995), who investigate 169 Korean initial public offerings listed on the Korean Stock Exchange during the period 1985–1989. Unlike previous international evidence, their results reveal that the Korean IPOs outperform seasoned firms with similar characteristics. Similarly, Paudyal et al. (1998) find that the performance of IPOs in Malaysia is not different from the performance of the market portfolio. Furthermore, Xia and Wang (2003) for China, Omran (2005) for Egypt, Madhusoodan and Thiripalraju (1997) for India, Durukan (2002) for Istanbul, Corhay et al. (2002) for Malaysia, Allen et al. (1999) for Thailand, etc., report that IPOs perform better than market index or the other benchmarks.

The mean abnormal performance of IPOs from different countries is reported in Table 1. With the exception of above mentioned countries, IPOs in all reported countries underperform over a period of 3 to 5 years subsequent to offering. A substantial number of articles provide empirical evidence of IPOs’ long-run performance across countries. However, in some countries, the long-run performance is more pronounced such as Australia, Austria, France, Canada, Chile, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Hong Kong, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore, Spain, Great Britain, Tunisia, etc. Furthermore, in some markets, especially in China, India, France, Switzerland, etc., the evidence of long-run underperformance is unclear. More surprisingly, a positive abnormal performance has been observed in the Greek, Korean, Malaysian, Swedish Thai and Turkish markets (see Table 1).

sec.p: Opulent literature exists on the post-issue performance of unseasoned equity issues and on the possible explanations for varying behaviour of the same across different countries. Ritter (1991) in his seminal paper provides three possible explanations for this anomaly: (i) risk measurement, (ii) bad luck, or (iii) fads or over-optimism. His findings support the third explanation that investors may be over-optimistic about the future prospects of issuing firms and firms seem to exploit ‘windows of opportunity’, i.e., going public when market conditions are most favourable for the issuing firms. Based on Ritter’s (1991) findings, various studies have been undertaken to test the existence of long-run performance and its possible determinants and thus a variety of hypotheses have been developed and tested.

Ritter (1991) and Loughran and Ritter (1997) propose that long-run underperformance is the result of windows of opportunity or market timing hypothesis, according to which managers select the timing when market overvalues their stock to issue new equity, in order to take advantage of favourable market conditions to lower the cost of capital. Moreover, managers make use of their information superiority to time the offering. Jain and Kini (1994) and Pagano et al. (1998) also find evidence of use of windows of opportunity by IPO firms at the time of issue. However, Kang and Shivdasani (1999) find that underperformance persists even after the market timing variable is controlled for.

Underperformance of IPOs in the aftermarket period can also be attributed to the management of discretionary accruals by the IPO firms prior to the offer (Rangan, 1998; Shivakumar, 2000; Teoh et al., 1998). IPO firms exhibit unusually good operating performance (strong fundamentals) prior to the IPO by resorting to the practice of earnings management, thereby leading the investors to believe in optimistic future prospects of the firm. Teoh et al. (1998) find that issuers with very high accruals in the IPO year experience poor stock performance in the three years following the issue. In the long run, underperformance is caused with revaluation of firm to its original value.

Overvaluation of IPOs by investors (or the presence of fads) in the early aftermarket trading is also a possible cause of underperformance in the long run (Aggarwal and Rivoli, 1990; Ritter, 1991; Shiller, 1990). Such persistent underperformance brings into question the rationality of the majority of investors who hold IPOs in the long run. A direct implication of the fads explanation is that a negative association is expected to exist between the level of initial price reaction and the long-term performance. Due to over-optimism, investors overreact to the signals leading to high initial returns, but with release of public information, a price reversal is expected in the long-run. In other words, the overreaction or fads hypothesis argues that IPOs may be correctly priced but investors overvalue the new issues in the early aftermarket. Therefore, under the assumption of efficient markets, the price of IPOs should reach their equilibrium price leading to a negative correlation between initial returns and long-term performance of IPOs (Shiller, 1990). Hansen and Crutchley (1990), Jain and Kini (1994), Loughran and Ritter (1997) and Brav et al. (2000) provide evidence in support of role of investor over-optimism in explaining the long-run underperformance.

Underperformance of IPOs in the long run can also be due to divergence of opinion about the value of firm at the time of IPO, which declines with time (Miller, 1977). Miller (1977) assumes that there are constraints on shorting IPOs, and that investors have heterogeneous expectations regarding the valuation of a firm. If there is a great deal of uncertainty about the value of an IPO, the valuations of optimistic investors will be much higher than those of pessimistic investors (Ritter, 1997). Over time, with decrease in variance of opinions, the marginal investor’s valuation will converge towards the mean valuation, and its price will fall. Greater divergence of opinion exists for a company which is new as there is greater uncertainty about its future; however, the divergence of opinion reduces as the company develops an operating history (as it becomes easier to forecast its future earnings and dividends). The higher the divergence of opinion, the worse the long-run performance is likely to be (Miller, 2000).

It can thus be concluded that due to the earlier cited reasons and because the empirical findings are so diverse, the issue of long-term underperformance becomes more debatable as compared to the issue of initial underpricing. Notwithstanding, both short-term and long-term IPO returns are determined by the initial price and the efficiency of the mechanism through which this price is set, and opinions about what should be the characteristics of an optimal IPO mechanism are somewhat conflicting (Boutron et al., 2007). The research on the issue of extent and determinants of long-run performance of IPOs has produced varied results and it is thus important to further analyze them in order to draw definite and universally applicable conclusions.

sec.title: Database and Research Methodology
sec.p: Finally, firms with missing price data are also excluded from the sample. These criteria resulted in a final sample of 648 IPOs. The sample could not be extended beyond March 2002 as it allows the examination of IPO performance till March 2007. The period following 2007 is regarded as abnormal period and the performance of market has been considerably volatile and thus this period is excluded from the analysis. BSE Sensitive Index has been taken as representative of market for the sample IPOs. For calculating market returns and IPO returns, closing value of the index and closing share prices of IPO firms have been taken respectively.

The data has been collected from secondary sources. Issue-related data including data for issue price, gross proceeds raised from the issue, oversubscription and lead managers have been taken from Prime Database.1 Closing market prices of IPO firms and closing values for BSE-Sensex for calculating IPOs and market returns respectively have been taken from Capitacharts database. Finally, data for firm-specific variables has been collected from Capitaline database.2

sec.title: Measurement of Long-run Returns
sec.p: For evaluation of long-run performance of IPOs, it is important to correctly measure the long-run returns. Return here implies the reward an investor earns for subscribing to an IPO either directly with an application at the time of IPO or at the closing price on the first trading day. Literature documents several ways of measuring long-run performance; however, there is no consensus on the appropriate methodology. Of the applied methods, most of the prior studies employ cumulative abnormal return (CAR) and buy-and-hold return (BHR) for measuring long-run performance. Nevertheless the issue as to whether CAR or BHR should be used to measure the long-term price performance has been widely debated. For robustness purposes, this study incorporates both the CAR and BHR.

The aftermarket period includes the 60 months subsequent to IPO date, where months are defined as successive periods of 21 trading-days relative to the IPO date. Thus, month 1 consists of event days 1–21; month 2 consists of event day 22 through day 42 after listing, and so on. Following Ritter (1991), the cumulative abnormal return (CAR) of a portfolio with n IPOs is determined by changes in total return of the portfolio over a period of t months. Monthly benchmark-adjusted returns are calculated as the monthly raw return on a stock minus the monthly benchmark return for the corresponding month.

sec.title: Examination of IPOs
Extent of Long-run Share Price Performance of IPOs in India
sec.p: A perusal of Table 2 reveals that the number of IPOs in the sample is not evenly distributed over the sample period. Maximum number of Indian firms went public during 1994–95, followed by the year 1993–94 and 1992–93. On the contrary only three IPOs came during 2001–02 and only four and six IPOs were offered during 1997–98 and 1998–99 respectively. As a matter of fact about 80 percent of issues in the sample took place during 1992 and 1995 and the remaining issues were offered during April 1995 till March 2002. Likewise, the value of IPOs is not evenly distributed over the sample period. Maximum gross proceeds (₹ 2927.17 crore) were realized in the year 1994–95, followed by the years 1999–2000 and 2000–01. Surprisingly, the number of issues in 1999–2000 and 2000–01 are very less (23 and 38 respectively) as compared to a very high number of issues in the year 1994–95 (230), suggesting that gross proceeds raised per issue have increased considerably over the sample years. The same can be observed from the perusal of issue activity for years 1992 through 1995 which represent about 80 per cent of issues and the proceeds realized during the same period tune up to about 38 per cent of total proceeds, implying that unlike the decline in the number of issues in the later years of the sample, the gross proceeds raised have increased.

caption.p: Distribution of IPOs by Year of Issue

sec.p: To measure the long-run share price performance, various alternative techniques have been employed in the literature. Nonetheless, in the light of recent evidence there exists no consensus on the appropriate methodology for calculating long-run returns (Barber and Lyon, 1997; Brav and Gompers, 1997; Kothari and Warner, 1997; Lyon et al., 1999; etc.). This study considers different approaches to ensure robust results. Following Ritter (1991), the cumulative abnormal returns (CAR) have been calculated. However, Barber and Lyon (1997) suggested that the cumulative abnormal returns are the biased predictors of buy-and-hold abnormal returns and favoured the use of the latter over the former. According to them, long-term investors’ experience is better captured by compounding short-term returns to obtain long-term buy-and-hold returns. Thus both cumulative abnormal returns and buy-and-hold returns have been used to examine the long-run performance of IPOs. The comparison of the empirical results from different methods should be interpreted as an important check for robustness and consistency.

sec.title: Cumulative Abnormal Returns
sec.p: Table 3 documents the average market adjusted return (ARt) and cumulative average market adjusted returns (CARt) for IPOs offered during 1992–2002 for 60 months subsequent to listing. These returns exclude the initial returns from listing. An investigation of the table reveals that underperformance appears in the second year after listing and after the third year Indian IPOs do not exhibit any underperformance. Precisely Indian IPOs experience negative cumulative abnormal returns from seventeenth till thirty-seventh month following the issue. Based on the same, it can be said that an investor who invests in Indian IPOs will earn negative returns if he uses CAR strategy for investment till the thirty-seventh month. However, if the same is followed till sixtieth month, he would stand to gain significantly. Cumulative abnormal return by the end of sixtieth month is 116.87 per cent which is very high if compared to evidence from other countries (see Table 1). This finding is thus not typical of IPO studies, which frequently document the presence of significant negative long-run performance.

sec.title: Buy-and-hold Returns
sec.p: Barber and Lyon (1997) believe that CAR are the biased predictors of buy-and-hold returns. Gompers and Lerner (2003) also find that when returns are highly volatile, cumulative abnormal return method tends to misrepresent long-run performance. Consequently the return for sample IPOs have also been calculated for a buy-and-hold investment strategy, which presumes that an initial public offering is received at the first closing price and is kept in the portfolio over a period of t months. Buy-and-hold returns (holding period returns) have been measured from the listing price, so as to exclude the effect of underpricing in long-run returns. Furthermore, BHR and BHAR have been calculated. The overall holding period returns of IPOs in India for five years following the issue are given in Table 4.

sec.p: A perusal of Table 4 reveals that the buy-and-hold returns are positive for the first year (29.25 per cent) and decline in second and third year followed by a rise in fourth and fifth year of holding. The maximum buy-and-hold returns are earned if the IPO is held by the investor till the fifth year (148.63 per cent) Buy-and-hold abnormal returns show similar pattern of returns as buy-and-hold returns, but returns generated are smaller if calculated using the former strategy. Buy-and-hold abnormal returns is 22.69 per cent in the first year, and experience a decline in second and third year leading to negative returns in second, third and fourth year and provide 109.83 per cent return for the fifth year which is higher than those including initial returns. Holding period returns show notable increase in the fifth year though they are not statistically significant.

Indian IPOs thus provide evidence of very high abnormal returns in the long run. Except for the second and third years’ post-offering, IPOs exhibit very high returns in the five years subsequent to the offering, whether measured through cumulative abnormal returns or holding period returns strategy. However, in line with the literature, the long-run performance in India is sensitive to the benchmark employed. The long-run share price performance does not corroborate the international evidence of significant and unremitting underperformance in the long run. Accordingly, it becomes imperative to further check the patterns of IPO performance according to various firm characteristics. The following discussion aims to study various time-series and cross-sectional patterns of long-run share price performance of IPOs in India.

sec.title: Time-series and Cross-sectional Patterns of Long-run Performance
sec.p: This section documents various cross-sectional and time-series patterns of long-run returns to examine the possible explanations for the long-run performance of Indian IPOs. To analyze such patterns of performance of the sample firms, following Ritter (1991), Allen et al. (1999) and Singh and Mittal (2003), firms have been categorized on the basis of their initial returns, age, year of issue, issue size, issue price, oversubscription and the industry to which they belong.

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Initial Returns
sec.p: It is vital to study the relationship between the initial returns of IPOs and their share price-performance in the subsequent market period so as to determine whether long-run performance is affected by initial market response and to ascertain whether initial returns can provide help in predicting the behaviour of returns in the long run. Initial returns are measured as market adjusted returns on the first trading day of an IPO. Various studies have analyzed the relationship between initial returns and long-run performance. Aggarwal and Rivoli (1990), Shiller (1990), Ritter (1991), Jain and Kini (1994), Firth (1997), Loughran and Ritter (1997), Isobe et al. (1998), Allen et al. (1999), Brav et al. (2000), How (2000), Kooli and Suret (2003), Georgen et al. (2007) and Cai et al. (2008) have found a negative relation between the two. This can be explained through fads theory according to which markets are subject to initial fads and the IPO performance deteriorates as these fads diminish implying that high initial returns may be due to overvaluation and high optimism of the market which does not sustain in the long run, thereby leading to underperformance. On the contrary, Levis (1993), Durukan (2002) and Singh and Mittal (2003) hypothesize a positive relation between initial and long-run returns implying that high initial returns mean good long-run performance and vice-versa. The clear evidence on relationship between IPO’s initial return and its performance in the long run will help investors to plan their long-run investments in IPOs based on their initial performance. In order to determine the relationship between initial returns and long-run returns, long-run returns of IPOs have been divided on the basis of initial returns. Table 5 shows the relationship between initial returns of IPOs and their long-run returns over the five-year period subsequent to issue.

caption.p: Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Initial Returns

sec.p: A perusal of Table 5 reveals differences in the long-run performance of IPOs across all quintiles. The long-run performance displays a negative relationship with respect to the initial returns. Startlingly, the IPOs with very high initial returns underperform the most and the best long-run performance is recorded by those IPOs which earned initial returns of lowest quintile. IPOs with least initial returns perform significantly better than IPOs in other four quintiles. This gives support to fads hypothesis, according to which the presence of fads in the initial period leads to increase in investor over-optimism and overvaluation of IPOs by the market which helps IPOs to gather very high initial returns, however when these fads fade, the same IPOs earn negative returns. Ibbotson (1975) explains that such relation between initial and long-run performance could be attributable to the high underpricing by issuers to avoid future lawsuits. This finding is thus in line with that of Aggarwal and Rivoli (1990), Shiller (1990), Ritter (1991), Jain and Kini (1994), Firth (1997), Loughran and Ritter (1997), Isobe et al. (1998), Allen et al. (1999), Brav et al. (2000), How (2000), Kooli and Suret (2003), Georgen et al. (2007) and Cai et al. (2008).

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Age
sec.p: Ritter (1991) suggested that age is the proxy for ex ante uncertainty and that is the reason why the young firms, which are supposed to be riskier, have high underpricing. Based on the same it is expected that younger firms have higher initial returns as younger firms, though more riskier, have higher growth potential as compared to older firms which have realized their potential and exhausted the same (Allen et al., 1999; Singh and Mittal, 2003). In contrast, it is generally believed that older companies, having made a niche for themselves with proven capabilities, are less likely to be affected by market and shareholders’ sentiments, and should perform better in the long run. Ritter (1991), Firth (1997), Durukan (2002) and Georgen et al. (2007) find a positive relation between age and the long-run performance of IPOs. Table 6 segments the IPOs on the basis of their age at the time of offering, computed as one plus the difference between the year of offer and the year of incorporation.

A perusal of Table 6 shows that long-run returns for the firms with age less than three years is better than firms from all other age groups for the first four years. In the fifth year, highest returns are for firms aged between three and six. Age seems to significantly affect the returns for one year after issue, except for IPOs from the lowest age quintile.

caption.p: Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Age

sec.p: Thus it can be concluded that age positively and significantly affects the initial returns of IPOs, with younger firms underpricing a lot more than their older counterparts. However, in the long run, returns of newly formed and very young firms are better than those of other firms in the sample, implying that younger firms perform better in the long run and age has a negative relation with long-run performance of IPOs; the results are in line with the prior Indian evidence of negative relationship between age and long-run performance by Singh and Mittal (2003).

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by the Year of Issue
sec.p: Performance of IPOs may also vary on the basis of the year in which they were offered. It is generally believed that IPOs offered during periods of high IPO volume and high initial returns (such periods are referred to as hot periods), generally do not perform well in the long run as even an ordinary firm may get extraordinary returns in the initial period when market is buoyant and investors’ demand is high and only firms with very sound fundamentals and good future prospects would bring out an issue when market sentiment is not that upbeat. Usually, a large number of issues get floated in the hot market period and very few firms dare to offer their issues in the cold period due to fear of not so good market response to their issue. Ibbotson and Jaffe (1975), Ritter (1984), Ibbotson et al. (1988), Levis (1993), Jain and Kini (1994, 2000), Isobe et al. (1998), Pagano et al. (1998), Singh and Mittal (2003) and Georgen et al. (2007) have earlier examined the possible relation between the timing of the issue and IPO performance and they have found conclusive evidences of cautious timing of the issues by the managers corresponding to the prevailing market conditions. Jain and Kini (2000) have also attributed the increase in issue activity in certain periods to industry clustering. Thus, it would be useful to examine whether such market trends exist for Indian IPOs and whether they have any effect on share price performance of IPOs in the long run. Table 7 exhibits the share price performance of Indian IPOs split by their respective years of issue. It can be observed from the table that issues in 1998–99 and 2001–2002 continuously earn positive returns. Issues in 1992–93 have very high returns for the first two years. IPOs issued in 1999–2000 have significantly underperformed over the five-year period; the issues in this period correspond to the technology bubble period to which such underperformance may be attributable.

caption.p: Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Year of Issue

sec.p: To sum up, it can be said that variations exist in initial and long-run performance of IPOs in India across the different offering years. The years 1992–93 and 1993–94 experience very high returns for first two years after issue, which probably explains the large number of issues in 1994–95 and gives evidence of issue-clustering and fall in performance in these years thereafter; low returns for IPOs in 1994–95 probably explain the decline in issue activity in the following years. The continuous negative returns for issues in 1999–2000 and 2000–01 could be attributable to the technology bubble.

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Size
sec.p: Size of the issue, measured as gross proceeds earned from the issue may affect its long-run performance. It is generally believed that issues with smaller size resort to high underpricing; their aftermarket performance could be negative as they are riskier (Durukan, 2002; Firth, 1997; Georgen et al., 2007; How, 2000) but the conflicting view holds that such risk is accompanied by greater upside growth potential too, so possibly small issues can earn high returns in the long run as well (Allen et al., 1999; Cai et al., 2008; Corhay et al., 2002; Kooli and Suret, 2003; Levis, 1993; Singh and Mittal, 2003). It is presumed that small IPOs are related to the issues by small and young companies which have high potential for future growth. To investigate the relation between size of the issue and the aftermarket performance, the firms are segmented on the basis of size of their gross proceeds as documented in Table 8.

caption.p: Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Size

sec.p: It is evident that initial returns of IPOs for all sizes are high and significant with smaller size issues earning higher initial returns. However, the firms with smallest issue size have performed better than other firms in the long run, which is contrary to the existing evidence that a smaller issue is more likely to have a higher initial underpricing followed by a worse aftermarket performance. Issues in the lowest quintile record highest returns on listing and for all the five years post offering; the returns decline sequentially for the higher quintiles. It is however noteworthy that the issue size has a significant effect on initial returns but its effect on long-run returns is less pronounced. The findings are thus in contrast to the market overreaction hypothesis supported by Ritter (1991) and Levis (1993) and supports the negative relationship between size of the issue and long-run performance as found by Levis (1993), Allen et al. (1999), Corhay et al. (2002), Kooli and Suret (2003), Singh and Mittal (2003) and Cai et al. (2008), implying that the higher issue size does not guarantee good performance in the long run.

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Issue Price
sec.p: Issue price is the price at which an IPO is offered to the public. The issue price can affect the subscription of an IPO and thus may affect its share price performance. Long-run performance of IPOs segmented by issue price is reported in Table 9. It can be observed that the maximum issues in the sample have been priced at ₹10 and in the aftermarket period, these firms have performed better than all other firms. As can be observed from the table, with increase in issue price the initial returns witness a decline with maximum initial returns earned when offer price is set at ₹10 and the minimum when issues are priced at the maximum. Likewise, long-run performance for issues priced at ₹10 is significantly better than those offered at any other price and all returns are significantly negative for the issues with issue price ranging between ₹80 and ₹630.

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Oversubscription
sec.p: Oversubscription ratio of an IPO establishes its investors’ demand. A direct relation is expected between oversubscription and initial returns, that is, issues that are oversubscribed reflect high investors’ interest and are generally more underpriced. Nevertheless, such oversubscribed issues may not perform equally well in the long run as investor interest and optimism may be temporary which may be driven by fads or market sentiments. When such fads and positive sentiments subside, these firms may not deliver equally good returns, thereby leading to underperformance in the long run. Table 10 categorizes the initial and long-run returns of IPOs on the basis of their oversubscription at the time of issue.

caption.p: Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Issue Price
Long-run Performance of IPOs in India Categorized by Oversubscription

sec.p: Table 10 exhibits that oversubscription significantly affects the initial returns and returns over one year after listing only. There is an inverse relationship between subscription ratio and returns for first two years, with firms that are least subscribed earning higher returns in first and second years; such returns in both the years fall with increase in oversubscription. However, such pattern does not hold in the later years and oversubscription does not significantly affect the long-run performance of Indian IPOs after the first year following the issue. Thus, oversubscription taken as a proxy for investors’ demand can possibly explain the initial performance of IPOs and cannot be conclusively used as a measure for predicting long-run performance of IPOs.

sec.title: Aftermarket Performance of IPOs Categorized by Industries
sec.p: National Industrial Classification (NIC) has been followed to categorize IPOs into their respective industries. NIC classifies industries into 17 different categories (ranging from A to Q), based on the nature of their activities4. To analyze the characteristics of IPOs based on their respective industries Table 11 shows the mean and median sales, gross proceeds and age of IPOs categorized by industries. As can be observed from the table, issues offered during 1992–2002 are not evenly distributed across the industries. Manufacturing sector is the most represented in the sample, with 413 IPOs; for the same reason it has been further classified into chemicals, pharmaceuticals and drugs, and textiles industry and this leaves 218 IPOs in the manufacturing sector. Real estate, renting and business activities industry and financial intermediation industry also have high representation. However, no issues have taken place during 1992–2002 in industries of electricity, gas and water supply, public administration and defence, compulsory social security, activities of private households as employers and undifferentiated production activities of private households and extraterritorial organizations and bodies. Others in total include 98 IPOs from industries for which there are less than 30 IPOs, of which 17 firms are from agriculture, hunting and forestry, 5 from fishing, 7 from mining and quarrying, 18 from construction, 9 from wholesale and retail trade, repair of motor vehicles, motorcycles and personal and household goods, 7 from hotels and restaurants, 14 from transport storage and communications, 3 from education, 1 from health and social work and 17 firms from other community, social and personal service activities industry.

Substantial variations in sales and gross proceeds across industries can be observed from Table 11. Mean and median sales are higher than overall mean and median sales for all firms for manufacturing and financial intermediation industry. When manufacturing industry is further classified, annual sales for pharmaceuticals and drugs and other manufacturing firms are higher than those of chemicals and textiles firms. As far as the gross proceeds are concerned, mean and median gross proceeds are highest for financial intermediation industry followed by others and real estate, renting and business activities industry. Gross proceeds raised by manufacturing industry and its sub-industries are lower than other industries. There is not much difference in the median age across the industries; however, the mean age of financial intermediation industry is the highest.

tr.td: Real Estate, Renting and Business Activities

sec.p: Furthermore, it is desirable to examine whether the nature of industry has any bearing on the aftermarket performance of IPOs. For the purpose of finding out whether there exists any significant difference in the performance of IPOs across industries, the issuing firms have been categorized on the basis of industry. Table 12 shows the aftermarket performance of IPOs with respect to industries. It is evident that the performance of IPOs varies for firms in different industries across five years. Initial returns are very high for real estate, renting and business activities industry followed by financial intermediation and pharmaceuticals and drugs industry.

A perusal of Table 12 reveals that the returns in the first year are significantly positive for most of the industries. Long-run returns show an increasing trend for real estate, renting and business activities industry. Real estate, renting and business activities industry and financial intermediation industry are the best performers of all and earn positive returns throughout the five years post offering. After second year manufacturing industry has lower returns over the five years with the negative returns from second through fifth year after the issue; this may be attributable to the higher gestation period in manufacturing industry as compared to other industries. Such broad disparity in the long-run performance and the reported underperformance in many industries is consistent with the fads hypothesis of Ritter (1991).

sec.p: Like Ritter (1991), Allen et al. (1999) and Singh and Mittal (2003), IPOs show significant variations when classified on the basis of initial returns, age, year of issue, issue size, issue price, oversubscription and their industry. In a nutshell, it can be said that IPOs exhibit differences in time-series and cross-sectional patterns and these patterns thereby have an important bearing on the long-run performance of IPOs. The following section aims to investigate whether the same factors that affect the pattern of long-run performance of IPOs can also be used to determine their performance in the long run.

sec.title: Determinants of Long-run Share Price Performance of IPOs in India
sec.p: After analyzing the extent of long-run performance of IPOs in India, it is important to get definitive results as to what factors probably cause such performance. In order to assess the determinants of long-run performance of Indian IPOs, multivariate regression analysis has been undertaken. Based on the prior research, the variables have been identified and examined to explain the variations in the share price performance of IPOs (Allen et al., 1999; Cai et al., 2008; Chalk and Peavy, 1987; Corhay et al., 2002; Dimovski and Brooks, 2004; Firth, 1997; Georgen et al., 2007; Ghosh, 2005; How, 2000; Ibbotson et al., 1994; Isobe et al., 1998; Kooli and Suret, 2003; Levis, 1993; Michaely and Shaw, 1994; Omran, 2005; Paudyal, 1998; Ritter, 1991; Sehgal and Singh, 2008; Singh and Mittal, 2003).

sec.title: Description of Variables
sec.p: To investigate the possible determinants of long-run performance of IPOs in India, various variables have been identified and tested. Keeping the extant literature as a base, various issue-specific, firm-specific and market-specific variables have been identified which are expected to affect the performance of IPOs in the long run.5 Following parameters of IPO performance (defined in Table 13) have been used to determine the factors affecting the share price performance of IPOs in the long run:

list-item.p: Initial Returns: Initial return is measured as the market adjusted return on the first trading day of the IPO. Relationship between initial return and long-run performance of IPO firms has been extensively analyzed and various hypotheses have been propounded and tested to explain such relationship. It is presumed that IPOs with very high initial returns reflect positive investors’ sentiment in the issue and are expected to perform well in the aftermarket period (Durukan, 2002; Levis, 1993; Singh and Mittal, 2003). On the contrary, Aggarwal and Rivoli (1990), Shiller (1990), Ritter (1991), Jain and Kini (1994), Firth (1997), Loughran and Ritter (1997), Isobe et al. (1998), Allen et al. (1999), Brav et al. (2000), How (2000), Kooli and Suret (2003), Georgen et al. (2007) and Cai et al. (2008) have found a negative relation between the two which could be attributed to presence of fads in the initial market and investor over-optimism. Based on the same, it is hypothesized that IPOs with high initial returns experience negative aftermarket performance.

Issue Size: Issue size is measured as the gross proceeds (in ₹ Crore) from the issue. Larger issues are deemed to be better positioned in the market and there is lesser uncertainty regarding their future prospects. Besides, the small IPOs are associated with young small companies and are therefore influenced more by hypes in the stock market (Durukan, 2002; Firth, 1997; Georgen et al., 2007; How, 2000). In contrast, Levis (1993), Allen et al. (1999), Corhay et al. (2002), Kooli and Suret (2003), Singh and Mittal (2003) and Cai et al. (2008) provide evidence of inverse relation between issue size and IPO performance. Furthermore, Schultz (1993) and Jain and Kini (2000) document inverse relation between size of the offering and probability of delisting. Following the same line, Hensler et al. (1997) find a positive relation in firm survival time and issue size at the time of the offering. It is expected that firms with high issue size will have a better long-run performance.

Age: Age is measured as one plus difference between the year of going public and the year of incorporation. Firms that are older and have proven their capabilities are less prone to market tendencies and shareholder sentiments, experience lower ex ante uncertainty and are thus expected to perform better than younger ones (Durukan, 2002; Firth, 1997; Georgen et al., 2007; Ritter, 1991) though Allen et al. (1999) and Singh and Mittal (2003) find that younger firms perform better than the older ones, as they have higher potential for growth and better performance. Based on the observations of relationship of age and long-run performance from the cross-sectional and time-series patterns of long-run performance, it is expected that long-run performance of a firm is negatively related to its age.

Market Level: Market level has been measured as return on market index6 for one month preceding the offer. High market returns coincide with higher economic activity and large number of IPOs. Ritter (1991) and Loughran and Ritter (1997) propose that long-run underperformance is the result of windows of opportunity or market timing, according to which managers select the timing when market overvalues its stock to issue new equity, in order to take advantage of favourable market conditions to lower the cost of capital. It has been found that issues timed in hot market periods tend to underperform in the long run. Based on the same, it is expected that long-run performance of IPOs is negatively related to the market level at the time of the offering.

IPO Volume: Following Ritter (1991), IPO volume is defined as the number of issues in the issuing year, divided by 100. It is expected that periods of high IPO volume are generally followed by high issue activity, with large number of low-quality firms selected to go public. Ritter (1991), Allen et al. (1999) and Singh and Mittal (2003) find that issues offered during periods of high IPO activity tend to underperform in the long run. Thus, a negative relation is expected between IPO volume and long-run performance.

Inverse of Issue Price: Issue price is the price at which one unit of equity is offered to the public at the time of an IPO. Corhay et al. (2002) find a negative relation between long-run performance of IPOs and the inverse of issue price. However it is expected that higher the issue price, the lesser will be the demand for IPOs by the investors and thus, it is expected that the inverse of issue price is positively related to the long-run performance of IPOs.

Probability of Success in the Allocation: Probability of success in the allocation is measured from the number of times an issue is subscribed to. The absence of a feedback mechanism between demand and issue price implies that oversubscription reflects investors’ expectation of the long-run performance of the IPO. Although oversubscription might reflect low probability of success in the allocation, it is expected that such issues have good long-run performance. It is expected that firms with a lower probability of success in allocation are the ones which have good future prospects and sound past performance, and are thus expected to perform better in the long run. Consequently, it is anticipated that lower the probability of success, the better the long-run performance and greater the probability of success, the worse the long-run performance. Thus, a positive relationship between subscription ratio and long-run performance is hypothesized.

Market Return: Market return is measured as the return on market index (BSE-Sensex) for the corresponding period. Ritter (1991) and Levis (1993) find a positive relation between market return and share price performance. However, Firth (1997) and Allen et al. (1999) demonstrate a negative relation between the two. The share price performance is expected to be in line with the performance of the market. Therefore, a positive relation is expected between the market return and the long-run performance of IPOs.

Reputation of Lead Manager: The reputation of lead managers has been measured on the basis of size of issues managed by them. Following Megginson and Weiss (1991), reputation of lead managers has been measured as the percentage of size (gross proceeds) of all sample IPOs. If the issuing firm has more than one lead manager, the average of the lead manager’s share is used as the measure of lead manager’s quality for that firm. It is assumed that the greater the share of the lead manager, the greater is his reputation and higher is the quality of the issue. The prestige and reputation of lead managers of the issue are believed to be associated with the better performance of the firm. Thus, it is expected that the reputation of lead managers will have a positive relation with long-run performance of IPOs.

Firm Size: Firm size is measured as natural log of total assets prior to the IPO. It is expected that firms that have higher total assets available prior to the IPO, perform better as compared to those with lower issue size as high assets base serves as a shock absorber in times of need. Based on the same, Durukan (2002) and Georgen et al. (2007) find a positive relation between firm size and long-run performance. Therefore, it is hypothesized that firm size is positively related with the long-run performance.

Profits before Listing: Profits before listing are the average profits for three years before the IPO calculated as profits before interest dividend and taxes. Georgen et al. (2007) find that profits before listing are negatively related to the long-run performance. It may be due to the earnings management by the issuers, which may be done to show higher profitability of the firms prior to issue. To wade out the possible effect of earnings management, average profits for three years prior to listing have been taken and a positive relation is expected between profits before listing and the long-run performance of IPOs.

Sales Growth: Sales growth is the rate of growth of net sales in the year prior to the IPO. Firth (1997) finds a positive relation between the sales growth rate and the IPO performance in the long run. Increase in sales implies increase in business activities; thus, a positive relation is hypothesized between sales growth and long-run performance of IPOs.

Price Earnings Ratio: Price earnings ratio is the ratio of offer price of the IPO to earnings per share (EPS) at the time of issue. If the offering price is higher than the EPS at the time of the issue, it represents overvaluation of the issue and it is expected that such issue will not perform very well in the long run as the offer price is set higher than its actual worth (Durukan, 2002; Omran, 2005). In line with the findings of literature, a negative relation between price earnings ratio and the long-run performance is hypothesized.

Debt–Equity Ratio: Debt–equity ratio is the ratio of firm’s short- plus long-term debt to its equity measured one year prior to the issue. It depicts debt level in the firm capital structure prior to the IPO. Durukan (2002) find a positive relation between debt equity ratio of the firm before offering and its long-run performance. Higher debt level allows for higher profits for shareholders by leveraging with debts. Thus it is expected that higher debt level prior to the IPO is positively related with the long-run performance of IPOs.

Book to Market Ratio: Book to market value ratio is the ratio of book value of share at the time of IPO to closing price of IPO on the first trading day. Higher value of this ratio implies that fair value or actual value of shares is much higher than the market value, depicting the undervaluation of share and thus higher upside market potential. Firth (1997) and Corhay et al. (2002) find a positive relationship between firm’s book to market ratio and its performance in the long run. Thus, it is expected that a positive relation exists between book to market ratio and long-run performance of IPOs.

Industry: Aftermarket performance has been found to vary across firms belonging to different industries. Ritter (1991), Levis (1993), Firth (1997), Isobe et al. (1998), Hensler et al. (1997), Jain and Kini (2000), Kooli and Suret (2003), Singh and Mittal (2003) and Georgen et al. (2007) included industrial dummies to determine whether specific industries’ IPOs are more likely to perform better in the long run. Industrial dummies have been taken as control variables to determine any specific relation between industries and post-IPO long-run performance. Three industry dummies have been included for firms in manufacturing industry, financial intermediation industry, and real estate, renting and business activities industry; firms from all remaining industries form the reference category.

sec.title: The Model
sec.p:
Multiple regression analysis has been applied to examine the factors that may explain the long-run share price performance of Indian IPOs. This technique helps in identifying the extent and direction of relationship between the dependent variable and several independent variables. The R square and the adjusted Rsquare generated by it indicates the proportion of variation in the dependent variable explained by the independent variables. On the basis of existing literature, the following OLS regression model has been developed to find the determinants of long-run performance of IPOs in India:

Where
Y is the dependent variable
X1,X2, …. Xn are the various issue-specific, firm-specific or market-specific regressors (as defined in Table 13)
β1,β2,…., βn are coefficients to be estimated
εi is the disturbance term

In order to check the problem of collinearity between variables, Variance-Inflating Factors (VIFs) have also been computed for the explanatory variables. However, no problem of multicollinearity was found, though these results have not been reported in the present study. Furthermore, to check the autocorrelation in the disturbances εi, Durbin-Watson d statistics have been computed. These statistics have been reported for each regression. As a rule of thumb, if d is found to be 2 in an application, one may assume that there is no first order (serial correlation) autocorrelation, either positive or negative. All the techniques have been applied by using SPSS package Version 15.0.

sec.title: The Results
sec.p: In order to identify the possible determinants of long-run share price performance of Indian IPOs, pairwise correlations, univariate regressions and multivariate regressions7 have been run. Following Singh and Mittal (2003), stepwise regression analysis has been undertaken to identify the variables that significantly affect the IPO returns. To sum up the results of determinants of long-run share price performance of IPOs, Table 14 has been constructed which exhibits the significant variables that affect the share price performance of Indian IPOs for the first five years subsequent to the issue. As can be seen, initial returns, market return and inverse of issue price significantly affect the share price performance for all five years post listing. Of these, market returns and inverse of issue price have a positive effect on long-run share price performance.

sec.p: It is noteworthy that initial returns are negatively related with long-run returns. The negative sign of initial returns is consistent with the overreaction hypothesis, which states that market in the long run corrects the overvaluation caused in the initial period. The results however contradict the signalling hypothesis that predicts a positive relation between underpricing and long-run returns.

Market returns are positively related to long-run IPO returns, thereby signifying that share prices move in accordance with the prevailing market price. In other words, market movement positively and significantly affects the long-run share price performance of Indian IPOs. Inverse of issue price also positively affects the long-run performance, implying that lower the issue price the better will be the long-run performance and vice-versa. The issues offered at lower per unit price tend to have a better long-run performance as against those offered at higher prices.

Book to market value ratio also positively and significantly affects the long-run performance for first four years subsequent to listing. This ratio is a possible indicator of relative overvaluation of an IPO. A positive coefficient of this ratio implies that firms that are fairly valued or less overvalued will perform better than those which have been highly overvalued at the time of offer. It thus provides support to the market timing hypothesis.

IPO volume also affects performance of IPOs for the first two years after the issue. As hypothesized, IPO volume has a negative sign which implies that a large number of firms go public in high volume periods; however, such firms may not be financially sound and viable and thus tend to underperform in the long run. This finding is consistent with the market timing hypothesis, which states that low-quality firms prefer to go public in the periods of high issue activity and consequently do not sustain the high initial returns for long and thus underperform in the long run. Market level represents the return of market index preceding the offer. This variable has a significant and positive effect on returns for the first year. This finding implies that there is a positive effect of high market returns before the offering till about one year subsequent to the offering.

Firms from real estate, renting and business activities industry has a significant and negative coefficient for first two years, which implies that as compared to firms in other industries the performance of this industry is not good in the first two years after listing. However the coefficient is positive for the later years though not significant. Firms from financial intermediation industry have a positive association with long-run performance, though it is significant in the second and fourth year post-listing. A conclusion can be drawn that firms in financial intermediation industry perform better than firms in other industries. Firms from the manufacturing industry have significantly negative effect on long-run share price performance. However, IPOs from manufacturing sector have positive coefficient for first two years followed by a negative sign in the following three years. So it can be said that though insignificantly, but firms in manufacturing industry perform better than firms from other industries for first two years which is followed by a negative performance as compared to firms from other industries in the last three years, out of which they underperform most significantly in the fifth year post-issue.

Firm size significantly and positively affects the performance of IPOs for third and fourth year after listing. The coefficient has a positive (though insignificant) sign for the other years also. Thus, as hypothesized, size of the firm has a positive effect on the long-run performance of IPOs. Average profits before listing significantly and positively affect the long-run share price performance of IPOs in the fourth year after listing. Moreover, average profits before listing have a positive (though insignificant) coefficient for other years, which means that firms which had higher profits for three years before listing perform better than those with lower average pre-listing profits.

Issue size (measured as gross proceeds raised from the issue) and probability of success in allocation (measured from oversubscription) have significant and negative effect on the IPO returns in the first year after issue. Issue size has a negative coefficient for all five years implying that young and smaller firms associated with small sized IPOs perform better than older and more established firms. The negative sign of IPO size is consistent with the fads hypothesis.

Age, reputation of lead managers, sales growth, price earnings ratio (P/E) and debt–equity ratio (D/E) have been excluded from all models and do not significantly explain the performance variations of long-run share price performance.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This paper investigated the share price performance of Indian IPOs. It specifically examined the extent of long-run performance of Indian IPOs, their time-series and cross-sectional patterns and finally the various factors that explain its long-run share price performance. After the examination of extent of long-run share price performance, it can be concluded that Indian IPOs provide evidence of very high abnormal returns over the five years after the issue (except for a negative drift in second and third year after offering). The share price performance of Indian IPOs does not corroborate the international evidence of significant underperformance in the long run.

Indian IPOs show significant variations in their time-series and cross-sectional patterns, implying that long-run performance of firms differs significantly based on various issue-related and firm-related characteristics. Lastly, initial returns, market return and inverse of issue price significantly affect the share price performance for all five years after the IPO. The findings of determinants of long-run performance support windows of opportunity hypothesis and investor over-optimism hypothesis.
